title-group.article-title: Longitudinal linkages between depressive and posttraumatic stress symptoms in adolescent survivors following the Wenchuan earthquake in China: A three-wave, cross-lagged study

article-meta.aff: Beijing Normal University, People’s Republic of China

abstract.p: This study aimed to determine the relationships between depressive and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) symptoms in a sample of adolescent survivors following the Wenchuan earthquake in China. Two-hundred adolescent survivors were reviewed at 12, 18 and 24-months post-earthquake. Depression and PTSD were assessed by two self-report questionnaires: The revised Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale for Children and the Revised Child PTSD Symptom Scale, respectively. The cross-lagged structural equation analysis with latent variables indicated that the PTSD symptoms and depression could be considered as two distinct and high-correlated constructs, and depression symptomatology pre-event could predict post-event PTSD. Depression symptoms play a crucial role in the development of PTSD symptoms. Implications of the results for psychological service providers to children and youth are discussed.

body.p: As one of the most destructive of natural disasters, an earthquake that occurred in Wenchuan, China in 2008 caused widespread life and property losses. Adolescent survivors of this earthquake experienced significant psychological reactions; posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is often considered the most frequent of psychological reactions in the aftermath of disasters (Zeng & Silverstein, 2011). Numerous studies have documented that the rate of PTSD in adult and child survivors of earthquakes range from 4.5% to 95% (Bulut, Bulut, & Tayli, 2005; Eksi & Braun, 2009; Giannopoulou et al., 2006; Goenjian et al., 1995; Hsu, Chong, Yang, & Yen, 2002; Lai, Chang, Connor, Lee, & Davidson, 2004; Roussos et al., 2005; Zang, Zhang, & Wu, 2009). More importantly, PTSD is generally co-morbid with depression. For example, previous studies found that the rate of PTSD comorbid with depression ranged from 8% to 67.5% among adult survivors of earthquakes (Basoglu, Kilic, Salcioglu, & Livanou, 2004; Salcioglu, Basoglu, & Livanou, 2007), with a single instance of 75% among child survivors of earthquakes (Goenjian et al., 1995).

Nevertheless, although PTSD/depression comorbidity is prevalent in clinical treatment circumstances, the specific nature of this association remains unclear. Several possible mechanisms have been offered to explain the comorbidity between PTSD and depression following traumatic exposure. The first potential explanation is that the observed comorbidity results from the overlapping symptoms across the two disorders. For example, some studies disclose that among those individuals with a lifetime history of PTSD, the proportion of individual who met the criteria for a prior major depressive episode ranged from 48% to 55% (Elhai, Grubaugh, Kashdan, & Frueh, 2008; Kessler, Sonnega, Bromet, Hughes, & Nelson, 1995). Yet, some studies have implied that individuals with PTSD or prior depression did not tend to display more severe symptoms of both disorders (Blanchard, Buckley, Hickling, & Taylor, 1998; Franklin & Zimmerman, 2001), or experience impaired psychological psychosocial functioning (Stein, McQuaid, Pedrelli, Lenoz, & McCahill, 2000), or attenuated treatment responsiveness (Labbate, Sonne, Randal, Anton, & Brady, 2004).

The second hypothesis supposes that PTSD symptoms serve as a risk factor which increases the severity of depression. Breslau, Davis, Peterson, and Schultz (1997), for example, found that PTSD accentuated the risk for first-onset depression. One possible pathway is that depression results from feelings of incompetence and helplessness following unsuccessful attempts to control emotional distress or grief accompanying the traumatic event (Cohen & Mannarino, 2011; Goenjian et al., 1995; Mangelli et al., 2005). Another possible pathway is that the individual with PTSD symptoms elects social avoidance, which in turn leads to a withdrawal from interpersonal relationships.

In contrast, a further hypothesis suggests that PTSD symptoms are themselves a consequence of depression rather than a causal factor. Factors closely correlated with depression may play an important role in the development of PTSD, for example, to enhance negative affect (Merriman, Norman, & Barton, 2007) and reduce self-concept (Shahar, 2001). This view has recently been supported by a study which focused on the PTSD-depression comorbidity in a sample of Israeli victims of a single-event trauma (Schindel-Allon, Aderka, Shahar, Stein, & Gilboa-Schechtman, 2010; a similar study of the effects of Israeli conflict-experiences upon children is also relevant to this context, see Abel & Friedman, 2009).

Finally, co-morbidity of PTSD with depression may also come from the influence of the third factor or factors which are causally related to both conditions, such as a history of depression (Bromet, Sonnega, & Kessler, 1998; Kessler et al. 1995; Zaidi & Foy, 1994), the severity of trauma exposure (LaGreca, Silverman, Vernberg, & Prinstein, 1996; Schumm, Briggs, & Hobfoll, 2006; Vinck, Pham, Stover, & Weinstein, 2007), prior trauma history (Vinck et al., 2007), personality traits such as neuroticism and low self-esteem (Andrew, Hawton, Fagg, & Westbrook, 1993; Barnett & Gotlib, 1988; Zlotnick, Shea, Pilkonis, Elkin, & Ryan 1996), and emotional processing deficits (Litz, Orsillo, Kaloupek, & Weathers, 2000; Miller & Litz, 2004).

These explanations offer us important insights into the development and maintenance of PTSD and depressive symptoms. But some issues still need further examination. First, major findings have previously been obtained by means of cross-sectional design; although such research designs can yield indications of finding, they are limited in their ability to determine causal relationships. Second, of the existing prospective studies (e.g. Ginzburg, Ein-Dor, & Solomon, 2010; Schindel-Allon et al., 2010), none have considered pre-trauma variables (i.e. a diagnosis present before the trauma or prior traumatic experiences). Third, compared to adults, children and adolescents are particularly vulnerable to earthquakes; for example, they may also show developmentally related cognitive and emotional reactions (Bulut et al., 2005; Margolin, Ramos, & Guran, 2010). Identifying PTSD/depression comorbidity is important for creating effective intervention plans for childhood survivors of earthquakes. In addition, this co-occurrence between PTSD and depression also needs to be examined in a variety of different cultures.

In our study, we incorporate cross-lagged, latent variable structural equation modeling (SEM) to examine the reciprocal relationship between symptoms of depression and PTSD in adolescent survivors following the Wenchuan earthquake. The study aims are: To examine the prevalence rates of PTSD, depression and their co-occurrence; to assess whether PTSD symptom severity predicts depression; to determine whether depression symptoms can predict the severity of PTSD symptoms; and to examine whether PTSD and depressive symptoms can predict each other over time.

sec.title: Participants and procedures
sec.p: Data were collected as part of an extensive longitudinal study of child survivors after the Wenchuan earthquake. The sample consisted of 200 adolescents from several high schools located in the most severely affected earthquake area. The mean age of these adolescents was 15-years-old at the first measurement wave, with a range from 13.6- to 16.4-years-old. Of the 200 participants, 124 (62%) were female and 76 (38%) were male; with respect to their ethnicity, eight (4%) were identified as members of the Han ethnic group, four (2%) as belonging to the Tibetan ethnic group, 175 (87.5%) as members of the locally resident Qiang people, and 13 (6.5%) as members of other minor ethnic categories.

All participants were provided written informed consent procedures; human subjects/ethics approval was monitored by the Department of Psychology, Beijing Normal University. Three assessments were conducted by trained individuals with a degree in psychology. The 200 participants completed the first assessment at 12-months following the earthquake. At the second assessment, 18 months after the earthquake, 194 (97%) of the original 200 sample completed the survey; 109 (54.5%) completed the third assessment at 24-months following the earthquake. Biographic/demographic data suggests that dropouts at Time 2 and Time 3 did not differ from completers on PTSD and depression at Time 1.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Children’s depressive symptoms were measured using the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale for Children (CES-DC; Fendrich, Weissman, & Warner, 1990). The CES-DC was translated into Chinese and was validated with various Chinese populations (Wang, 1993). The CES-DC is a 20-item self-report measure for the assessment of emotional, cognitive, and behavior-related symptoms of depression. For each item, participants were instructed to assess the frequency of their reactions during the prior week. All items were evaluated with a four-point response option (0 = not at all, 1 = a little, 2 = some, 3 = a lot). Total possible scores range from 0–60, with higher CES-DC scores indicating increasing levels of depression. The Cronbach alphas of the scales in this study were 0.87 at Time 1, 0.88 at Time 2, and 0.90 at Time 3, respectively.

Posttraumatic stress symptom level was assessed with the Child PTSD Symptom Scale (CPSS; Foa, Johnson, Feeny, & Treadwell, 2001). The scale consists of a 17-item self-report measure designed to identify the presence and frequency of DSM-IV-defined PTSD symptoms in relation to the most distressing event. Children rate the frequency of symptoms such as ‘Feeling irritable or having fits of anger’ during the past two weeks on a four-point Likert scale (0 = not at all/only at one time to 3 = almost always, or five or more times a week). Total CPSS scores range from 0–51; subscale scores range from 0–15 for Re-experiencing, 0–21 for Avoidance, and 0–15 for Arousal. Consistent with Foa et al. (2001), we found the Cronbach alpha of the measures was high (0.84 at Time 1, 0.88 at Time 2, and 0.85 at Time 3, respectively).

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: Descriptive analyses were conducted to calculate the prevalence rate of PTSD and depression and the descriptive statistics for the measures of PTSD and depression. Pearson correlations were calculated to examine the associations between PTSD and depression cross-sectionally and longitudinally.

Cross-lagged analyses were conducted with AMOS 7.0 software using the Maximum Likelihood (ML) iteration procedure. Degree of model fit was assessed using the following fit indices: The chi-square, the normed-chi-square tests (Normed χ2; Jöreskog, 1969), the Tucker–Lewis Index (TLI; Tucker & Lewis, 1973), the Comparative Fit Index (CFI; Bentler, 1990), and the Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA; Steiger, 1980). Conventionally, a value of less than 2 for the normed-chi-square tests is considered as a good indicative of model fit (Carmines & McIver, 1981). The index of the TLI and the CFI indicated the model fit well with the data when these values were beyond 0.95 (Hu & Bentler, 1999). In addition, models are said to fit the data well when the RMSEA is less than 0.06 (Hu & Bentler, 1999).

To handle missing values, we used full information maximum likelihood (FIML) estimates (Anderson, 1957) that are enabled by AMOS 7.0. Compared with conventional methods of dealing with missing data (e.g. listwise deletion, pairwise deletion, or means imputation), the results produced by the FIML method are less biased and more reliable (Muthen, Kaplan, & Hollis, 1987). Thus, the SEM analysis in our study was based on the total sample of 200 individuals.

In addition, to test for differences in model fit, we used the test of small differences in fit, which is recommended by MacCallum, Browne, and Cai (2006). Comparable to the more commonly used χ2 difference test, the null hypothesis of small differences in fit suggests that if this difference is greater than an a priori specified small difference, a nonsignificant statistical test indicates that the true difference is small. For this study we followed the guidance of MacCallum et al. (2006) and set α = 0.05, REMSEAA = 0.06, REMSEAB = 0 .05 (REMSEAA and REMSEAB represent the a priori specified small difference in fit for conducting the test).

sec.title: Characteristics of the study sample
sec.p: For illustrative purpose, we report the prevalence rate for PTSD and depression. Based on the DSM-IV (American Psychiatric Association, 2000), subjects were identified as having full PTSD according to the following criteria: (a) one or more items of an Intrusion subscale scored greater than 2 or 3; (b) three or more items of the Avoidance subscale scored greater than 2 or 3; (c) two or more items of the Hyper subscale scored greater than 2 or 3. According to these criteria, the prevalence rate of PTSD at Time 1 was 17.5%; and at Times 2 and 3 it was 19.0%, 16.5%, respectively. Weissman, Orvaschel, and Padian (1980), the developers of the CES-DC, stipulate a cutoff score of 15 as being indicative of depressive symptoms in children and adolescents. According to these criteria, the prevalence rate for depression at Times 1, 2, and 3, were 82.5%, 85.6%, and 89.9%, respectively. The co-morbidity of depression and PTSD at Times 1, 2, and 3, was 17.5%, 19.0%, and 16.5%, respectively.

In order to describe the study sample, scores for PTSD and depression symptom severity were computed by summing the 17 CPSS items and the 20 CES-DC items to create PTSD and CPSS indices. The means and Standard Deviations of these measures are presented Table 1. The intercorrelations among PTSD and depression, without disattenuation for measurement error, are also presented in Table 1. sec.title: Phase 1: Measurement model results
sec.p: We established two measurement models including six latent variable constructs: Depression and PTSD symptoms at Times 1, 2, and 3. At each time-point, PTSD latent variable were evaluated by scores for the CPSS-subscales Intrusion, Avoidance and hyper (Foa et al., 2001), whereas depression latent variable were indicated by means of somatic, depression, positive, and interpersonal factors (Barkmann, Erhart, Schulte-Markwort, & The BELLA Study Group, 2008; Li, Chung, & Ho, 2010).

In the first measurement models (Model 1), correlations were specified between all latent constructs. The error terms of the manifest variables at different measurement waves were permitted to correlate to each other (Cole, Ciesla, & Steiger, 2007). For example, the error term of the intrusion manifest variables at Time 1 were correlated with the same error terms at Time 2 and Time 3, and these error terms of intrusion at Time 2 and Time 3 were also correlated with each other. The factor loading of the manifest indicators on their respective latent variables were estimated freely. The model fit data well (χ2(153) = 217.98, p < 0.001, χ2/df = 1.450, CFI = 0.972, TLI = 0.957, RMSEA = 0.046).

The second measure model (Model 2) was identical to the first model except that the factor loadings of analogous manifest indicators were constrained to equality across different points in time in order to ensure measurement invariance over time (Hoyle & Smith, 1994). The measurement model still fit the data well (χ2 (167) = 242.16, p < 0.001, χ2/df = 1.450, TLI = 0.955 CFI = 0.967, RMSEA = 0.048). The test of small difference indicated that Models 1 and 2 did not differ significantly in fit; thus, we favored the more parsimonious Model 2 and retained the longitudinal constraints on factor loading in the subsequent analyses.

In second the measurement model, all of the loadings of the manifest indicator onto their respective latent variables were statistically significant, ranging from 0.37–0.92. The correlation between all latent variables was strong and statistically significant, ranging from 0.53–0.90.

We also examined a one-factor model of PTSD and depression, in which all indicators at each time point loaded on one common factor. The fit of this model was low (χ2 (186) = 623.74, p < 0.001, χ2/df = 3.353, TLI = 0.747, CFI = 0.810, RMSEA = 0.109). Although we did not formally test the difference in fit because the one-factor and the two-factor models are non-nested models, the fit indices clearly indicate in favor of the two-factor model.

sec.title: Phase 2: Structural model results
sec.p: In this phase, we formulated two structural cross-lagged models, using the measurement model specified by Model 2. We converted cross-time covariance to regression estimation; for example, a latent variable at Time 2 is predicted by the same variable at Time 1 (The Autoregressor) and the other latent variable at Time 1. The cross-lagged paths indicate the influence of one variable on the other, after controlling for the stability of the variable over time (Finkel, 1995).

In the first cross-lagged model (Model 3), all structural coefficients were freely estimated. Model fit was good (χ2(167) = 241.34, p < 0.001, χ2/df = 1.445, TLI = 0.955, CFI = 0.968, RMSEA = 0.047). In the second cross-lagged model (Model 4), we constrained the structural parameters to be equal across all three time intervals. Model still fit the data well (χ2(171) = 244.45, p < 0.001, χ2/df = 1.428, TLI = 0.957, CFI = 0.968, RMSEA = 0.046). The difference in fit between Models 3 and 4 was not statistically significant. Consequently, we favored the more parsimonious Model 4 and retained the longitudinal constraints on structural coefficients in the subsequent analyses. To arrive at the most parsimonious model (Model 5), we repeated the analyses after dropping out the non-significant structure paths (Bentler & Moojaart, 1989). This model evinced a good fit (χ2(172) = 244.45, p < 0.001, χ2/df = 1.423, TLI = 0.958, CFI = 0.968, RMSEA = 0.047). The association among all latent variables is present in Figure 1. Figure 1.

Considering content overlap between the CPSS and CES-DC (‘having trouble concentrating’, ‘having trouble falling or staying asleep’, and ‘having much less interest or doing things you used to do’, Elhai et al., 2011), we analysed repeatedly the structure model after omitting three PTSD items that proved to be conceptually related to CES-DC. The model fit was virtually unaltered (χ2(171) = 237.46, p < 0.001, χ2/df = 1.389, TLI = 0.959, CFI = 0.970, RMSEA = 0.044). The stability coefficient is 0.83 and 0.87 for depression, and 0.40 and 0.44 for PTSD. The cross-lagged coefficient is 0.32 and 0.35 for the effect of depression on PTSD, and 0.09 and 0.10 for the effect of PTSD on depression.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We used a cross-lagged SEM with latent variables to examine the temporal sequence of depressive and PTSD symptoms in a sample of adolescent survivors following an earthquake experience. Several key findings emerged. First, consistent with previous studies (Blanchard et al., 1998; Grant, Beck, Marques, Palyo, & Clapp, 2008) our results also suggested that although the correlation between PTSD and depressive symptoms was high, these two disorders are better conceptualized as two distinct constructs. And, even after controlling for overlap content between PTSD and depressive symptom criteria, the association of these symptoms at different time-points still remained strong. Thus, this strong association between PTSD and depressive symptoms may more likely be the result of common risk factors which are correlated with both PTSD and depressive symptoms (e.g. pre-existing depression symptoms, and personality characteristic) than the over-lapping symptoms of these two disorders.

Secondly, we did not discern any influence by PTSD symptoms on depression (as was found in a 20-year longitudinal study of war veterans; Ginzburg et al., 2010). Our results were consistent with the Schindel-Allon et al. study (2010), which focused on the PTSD-depression co-morbidity in a sample of Israeli victims of a single-event trauma. Schindel-Allon and colleagues’ interpretation was that that the 12-week time-frame of their study was insufficient to detect the effect of PTSD symptoms on depression and that such a relationship would not emerge until later in the course of post-trauma. Yet, when examining the influence of adolescent PTSD symptoms on depression in a far longer time frame (up to two years), we still did not find evidence that PTSD symptoms predict depression. Therefore, this effect may be less prevalent than previously surmised.

Conversely, our results also suggest that depression symptoms predict subsequent post-traumatic distress symptoms, even after adjusting for the prior post-traumatic distress symptoms among adolescent survivors of an earthquake. The possible mechanism is that depressive symptoms such as negative self-evaluation may hinder an individual’s motivation to engage in exposure to trauma-related reminders (Schindel-Allon et al., 2010). This reduced self-efficacy may restrain individuals from dealing with trauma-related stimuli that are crucial for exercising the self-regulatory process. Another possible mechanism is that an inflexible emotional response leads individuals to fail to shift their emotion to reflect changing context or conditions (Coifman & Bonanno, 2010; Rottenberg, Gross, & Gotlib, 2005). Thus, existence of pre-existing depressive symptoms may play a crucial role in the development of PTSD. That is, adolescents with high levels of depressive symptoms are more likely than their low-depression counterparts to experience increases in post-traumatic distress.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: This study has several limitations. First, we did not collect data on pre-trauma morbidity (i.e. diagnoses present before the trauma and data on prior traumatic experiences) and the data collected at Time 1 was obtained one year post-trauma. These variables affecting the reaction to traumatic event deserve future attention. Second, we accessed PTSD and depression symptoms by self-report questionnaire, rather than by clinical interview. Contrasted with interview-based measures for diagnosis, self-report measures may have overestimated the prevalence of these disorders. In addition, the association between PTSD and depression was also bolstered by this self-report measure because of the shared method variance. Third, in our study we focused on the linkage between depressive and PTSD symptoms in a sample of adolescent earthquake survivors. To the extent that the relationship may vary as a function of trauma type, future research need to test these results in other circumstances of trauma such as exposure to armed-conflict or sexual assault. Our study sample was also relatively small (n = 200) and it will require a replication among larger samples to increase confidence in our conclusions.

sec.title: Implications for psychological service providers
sec.p: These results, which confirm the prevalence rates for PTSD and depression at three measured points post traumatic-event, strongly indicate the need for psychological service providers to be ready to render to child-survivors of earthquakes a systematic, planned, and long-term developmental intervention. School psychologists play diverse roles, which potentially can make a critical difference for children’s welfare in times of crisis. Within school-systems their referent power can create considerable leverage in effecting desired changes for children through their work with influential stakeholders (Cook, Jimerson, & Begeny, 2010). Yet, services are not equivalently distributed across national contexts. A recent survey reported an international estimate of about 76,100 school psychologists across 48 countries as of 2007 (Jimerson, Stewart, Skokut, Cardenas, & Malone, 2009); the ratio of school psychologists to school-aged children was estimated at 1: 20,000. However, in Asia, specifically including China, where the World’s largest population of children live, the actual number of psychological service providers available to serve schools is unknown (Jimerson et al., 2009). Nonetheless, developing models are emerging for the delivery of psychological services even to under-resourced settings, internationally, upon which providers may draw (Rees & Seaton, 2011). Such resources include programmatic templates for ‘strengthening cultural sensitivity in school-based disaster mental health services’ (Heath, Nickerson, Annandale, Kemple, & Dean, 2009, p. 347).

Although adolescent survivors may receive some immediate counseling and psychological interventions from local educators and psychological volunteers, such help is typically brief, episodic, short-term, and sporadically provided. It is unusual for such support to be available 36-months post-event. It is for that reason that Lin, Wu, Hou, Fu, and Zang (2009) proposed a comprehensive school-based psychological assistance model for China, including the provision of systematic training for educators, adjustments to the mental health services of local educational systems and the integration of external sources from parents, schools, and non-governmental organizations. Of this array of potential resources, schools are the locales preeminently situated to provide interventions following disasters (Heath & Cole, 2011). Such school-based interventions might include, for example, therapeutic activities (Webb, 2011); the recognition of reminders that may trigger grief and the direct teaching of stress-management strategies (Cohen & Mannarino, 2011); and developmentally-appropriate, targeted activities specific to adolescents rather than those derived from adult-models (Balk, Zaengle, & Corr, 2011), particularly where there is evidence of co-existing developmental or other disabilities (Sormanti & Ballan, 2011). School psychologists, counselors, teachers, and peers can strengthen emotional support and ease painful feelings associated with grief (Cohen & Mannarino, 2011; Heath & Hudnall, 2011; James, Logan, & Davis, 2011; Jerome, 2011; Nastasi, Jayasena, Summerville, & Borja, 2011; Openshaw, 2011). Heath and Cole (2011) provide a comprehensive list of resources and strategies educators may use to ease the grief experience of grieving adolescents and children including lesson plans, prompts for classroom discussion, scripts for school psychologists to incorporate, and activities with grief-themed children’s literature. In addition, our result implying that depression after a traumatic event leads to an increase in post-traumatic distress may also have important practical implications. It implies that school psychologists need to assess depressive symptoms as part of an overall evaluation of vulnerability and resilience factors prior to initiating treatment. These results also suggest that interventions to diminish depressive symptoms may themselves be helpful in alleviating PTSD symptoms and even preventing its development. Thus, as an alternative to the immediate initiation of treatment for PTSD, school psychologists can encourage adolescent victims of earthquakes to re-engage in rewarding and meaningful activities in order to reverse behavioral patterns of withdrawal and avoidance (Turner & Jakupcak, 2010; Wagner, Zatzic, Ghesquiere, & Jurkovich, 2007).

Schools are a natural source for social support; school psychologists, teachers, parents, and other educational professionals need to foster collaboration to provide childhood survivors of natural disasters greater social support, and bolster their interpersonal relationships—which may in turn immunize them from the effect of the disaster, enhance mastery of the experience, and minimize or avoid PTSD.
